project.teaser: TRAILS proposes a holistic approach to identifying the conditions for skills gaps and shortages across European countries and to contributing to policy actions. Its approach involves all conceptual and theoretical models of optimal skills match and utilization by workplaces...
project.objective: TRAILS proposes a holistic approach to identifying the conditions for skills gaps and shortages across European countries and to contributing to policy actions. Its approach involves all conceptual and theoretical models of optimal skills match and utilization by workplaces, new methodologies for measuring skill gaps, and understanding optimal ways to skills upskilling and reskilling. It involves novel primary datasets, state-of-the-art big datasets from administrative records matched to firms and workplaces, innovative inquiries with large secondary datasets that are merged with taxonomies and other sources to enable pathbreaking analyses, field and stated preference experiments, along with boost samples of groups of particular interest, such as platform workers and other stakeholders. All these elements will produce a canvas that enables a new framework for identifying the conditions and elements required for developing skills matched to the needs. It will allow the inspection of relevant behavioural, societal, and cultural dimensions affecting individuals' participation and choice of training and learning programmes. Moreover, the project will propose aims and objectives for basic and transferable skills that are most conducive to European labour mobility towards the green and digital jobs of the future. Finally, the project will propose ways to optimize the use of new technology-enhanced ways to bridge the gap between labour supply and demand in matching skills to needs. Via the usage of AI methods and the large-scale piloting, the project will propose ways that empower skills profiling and intelligence to raise awareness of training programmes matched to the needs of individuals and the jobs of the future for European labour markets. Ultimately, a TRAILS web-based tool will be developed to bring together new datasets and insights for policy makers and to raise citizens’ awareness regarding transferable skills and training programmes.
project.title: Enabling data analytics for actions tackling skills shortages & mismatch
project.keywords: new skills gaps indices, novel primary datasets, labour mobility, digital jobs, AI methods, transferable skills, fair transition, resilient workplaces

result.title: COMPARE I: Skills mismatching in Europe pre- and post-pandemic
result.description: Using most recent secondary data, this deliverable informs policy makers regarding country heterogeneity in horizontal and vertical skills mismatching and the changes that have occurred during the last decade.

result.title: QUESTION I – Review and Analytics of the Core Secondary Datasets
result.description: This deliverable entails the presentation and visualization of the descriptive statistics of the core secondary data overall and by country.

result.title: QUESTION III – Design of Interventions and Experimental Protocols
result.description: Specify in detail the cases studies and the protocols for the lab- and field experiments to take place with regard to the four use cases of our project. The number of participants, the control variables and any preliminary actionsneed to be considered for successfully implementing the experiments.

result.title: INTEGRATE I: TRAILS portal architecture, design and integration documentation
result.description: Documentation about the architecture and design of the TRAILS portal, including description of integration with 3rd party tools and services.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - TRAILS (Enabling data analytics for actions tackling skills shortages & mismatch)
result.teaser: The TRAILS project aims to deliver new insights and tools to bridge the gap between labour supply and demand by promoting shared awareness and co-development of skills tailored to the future needs of European labour markets: TRAILS uniquely leverages novel, country-specific...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

result.title: COORDINATE I: Project Administrative, Technical & Data Management Handbook
result.description: This handbook will enclose all procedures and guidelines for the administrative andmanagement requirements of the project. The innovation strategy is defined in D8.1 in terms of ensuring the project excellence in accordance with the Horizon Europe program and call requirements. It will report the required processes and procedures for assessing the quality and the guidelines and risk assessment plans of the project. Finally, it will address the lifecycle and public availability of research data generated by the project.

result.title: REVIEW III – Functional requirements for the TRAILS innovations
result.description: Report on specifications about TRAILS’s technological advances. This deliverable will include a detailed description of the tools to be developed during the duration of the project.

result.title: QUESTION II – Design of Survey Instruments
result.description: Design of the household survey, which will enable primary data collection from some 24 EU countries, plus some 4 countries that are EU candidates or neighbouring the EU. The custom household survey will serve a primary data catalyst in following analysis, experimentation and policy implications. It will design in detail and scientificrobustness the layout of the survey to successfully elicit European’s citizens beliefs, attitudes and behavioural biases towards topics regarding skills matching and the choice of training programmes.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
